snippet.textDisplay: I know that I'm super late and no one cares, but as someone that was raped and genuinely does not care about basketball or Kobe, this is my opinion. But the fact is that it sounds like Kobe felt horrible that she felt negatively about it and that is how it is.  I don't think this woman should have been doxxed or that she should lose her job, but it seems like she was just trying to get a spotlight in the wake of someone's death.  Again, I don't particularly care about Kobe, but it seems like she made a pretty shitty decision.

snippet.textDisplay:
Kobe's accuser refused to testify because Kobe and his legal team dragged her name through the mud in highly publicized ways the whole time leading up to the trial and she was terrified because she was getting death threats and constant harassment from Kobe fans. This is pretty common with high profile rape cases. For example, Christine Blasey Ford still hasn't returned to her professorship at Palo Alto University and has had to move 4 times since she testified against Brett Kavanaugh. (NPR 11/2018). She still receives death threats and gets doxxed frequently.


If you have a shadow of a doubt if Kobe did rape her then please read the daily beast article. It showcases the transcript of the accuser and Kobe's interviews with the police and its utterly obvious that he raped her. They even pulled his DNA during her rape test and her blood was on his t-shirt. On top of all of that, he settled her civil case. He did it.


I know most people, myself included, don't want to think he did especially since his tragic death but he raped that girl. And while there don't seem to be any other credible accusations against him since then which shows he changed for the better he still raped a girl almost 10 years younger than him. Its hard to square that fact with our country's collective reverence of him.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the Kobe incident was distasteful because she chose the week of his death to highlight the worse thing he had ever done. Had she done a full opinion piece on the man's life-- good and bad-- she would've done her job as a journalist at painting an entire picture of him, flawed and all. I think it was a matter of timing and the fact that she hid behind someone else's old article instead of making a real statement regarding her feelings as a sexual assault survivor surrounding someone as loved as Kobe was. He was more than that one incident to a lot of people and while I understand her discomfort at the idea of celebrating a man with such a history, it would've seemed less petty if she had made a point to remark on the complexities of being a "girl dad" and an alleged perpetrator of sexual assault then just sharing an unflattering article while others mourned him. It came off tactless.

snippet.textDisplay: I don’t think it’s appropriate to bring up past allegations after a tragic death, especially if all the details of the incident weren’t made public. That said, I also don’t think she deserved to be fired and at worst she should have been spoken to about it. Kobe made a mistake, and nobody but him and the victim could know for certain if it was an act of malice, selfishness, or a miscommunication. If we don’t know, maybe it’s not our place to judge the man right now. All we know is that she wasn’t very happy about it, and we can empathize with the victim without assuming that Kobe committed something so bad that it was worth minimizing his death over.
snippet.textOriginal: I don’t think it’s appropriate to bring up past allegations after a tragic death, especially if all the details of the incident weren’t made public. snippet.textDisplay: Seperate to the death penalty debate, regardless of his crime a fair trail is of the upmost importance to all justice systems. If there is no sound basis for what his lawyers are arguing, let it be found so, if there is a sound basis, that must be considered. Self represented litigants are especially vulnerable in the justice system, most prominently from disenfranchised socio-economic, marginalised, and minority backgrounds. Deny him the right to have his mental capacity assessed and ultimately you deny others as well. His own protestations about his mental capacity carry no weight in comparison to the assessment of professionals. To pick and choose a persons right to access justice based on their crime is unjust at its core.

snippet.textDisplay: as a survivor myself of sexual assault, it does bother me seeing someone so glorified in death.  i can't remember which celeb phil was quoting yesterday, but she said that he can both be a sports hero and have a blemish on his personal record, so to speak.  it's like that victim doesn't even matter and it all goes away and is forgotten because he was a great athlete that died tragically.  there is no harm in making sure that both sides of the story are told.  it is always a tragedy when anyone dies, and i am by no means happy that he passed and we shouldn't be ignoring his athletic achievements, but silencing the sexual assault and pretending it didn't happen harms survivors.  it makes us feel like it doesn't matter if the abuser is a celebrity or hot shot.  that reporter should never have gotten fired.  she's a victim too and she feels the same thing we all do when this happens.  you may not think it's that big of a deal, but it is.  if i may quote ERB "i'm not denying your fame, i'm just saying they should put an asterisk next to your name."

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who's mom works at a newspaper (for nearly 30 years) and is in a similar position, I can both see how the big wigs up top decided that for her, and why it's so bad. Journalists are here to give us the news. They're not personalities to give us what they think about the news. There's been a massive cultural push to make them into personalities, while newspapers still want them to be good little journalists who follow their rules so they can make more money and keep their heads above water (the pay gap between journalists and company leaders is astounding. Journalists hardly make anything). What they did was so so so backwards to what being the news and the press is all about. Don't go after the journalists, guys--go after the people who are telling them what they're allowed to publish.
snippet.textOriginal: As someone who's mom works at a newspaper (for nearly 30 years) and is in a similar position, I can both see how the big wigs up top decided that for her, and why it's so bad. snippet.textDisplay: The lawyers defending the white supremacist murderer are entirely correct. This isn’t a matter of trying to let a killer walk free, it’s a point of justice. We have to put the man through the court system, because we deserve to be able to prosecute him as a nation and a society. Denying him a proper defense would mean that for the rest of history that killer’s rightful punishment would have an asterisk next to it, and he doesn’t deserve the nuance of an asterisk. Get him lawyers, try him again, sentence him again, and remove him from my country forever.

snippet.textDisplay:
There hasn't been a RAID ad for a while until this video. I thought maybe you guys decided that integrity in a news organisation is more important than the stack they throw your way for every spot, but nope... still promoting a product that sees children developing gambling habits and addicts in financial hardship from a company owned by the second largest slot machine manufacturer on the planet.

I stopped supporting Phil through DeFranco Elite and merch as soon as he started running those ads and it made me rethink my position entirely on Phil and the direction the company is going. If any of you give a crap about scruples in business and actually wanted to see PDS and his other projects develop into reputable and influential works, please stop supporting Phil while they are still willing to sell out to a exploitative and ethically bankrupt companies like Plarium and Aristocrat Leisure Limited.

Some copy paste:

To anybody who holds Phil and Rogue Rocket to a higher standard than that of conventional or mainstream media organisations, please read on because there is a disturbing fact that only a small percentage of Phil and Rogue Rocket's audience seem to be aware of and even fewer who care.

Right now there are regular sponsorship spots being given to Plarium and their games on the Phil DeFranco show. Plarium is a subsidiary of Aristocrat Leisure Limited, which is a gambling machine manufacturer. They are the second largest manufacturer of slot machines in the world and in 2017 they spent around $1.4 billion acquiring Plarium and Big Fish Games. In short, Phil is regularly promoting gambling companies that are currently being investigated and even facing class action lawsuits and a mountain of scrutiny for unscrupulous and grossly unethical business practices.

If you or your team vetted that company you should have encountered a wealth of info highlighting why there are concerns raised about their dealings and products. From gameplay and pay2win algorithms modeled almost exactly like slot machines (I'll repeat this for emphasis: Plarium was acquired in 2017 by Aristocrat Leisure Limited: literally a gambling machine manufacturer that get the bulk of their revenue from half-demented retirees and gambling addicts pissing away pensions on rigged machines in dark corners of casinos), to entirely fake "gameplay" trailers which are being marketed largely at children, to the actual numbers ie. average spend per user and daily revenue from in game transactions being huge red flags about the nature of these games and how they operate.

The fallout of their demonstrably criminal misconduct is millions of people with severe addictions that have lead to tens of thousands of cases of financial hardship and they are subject to none of the regulations that gambling operators have to be compliant with despite the games being nothing more than rebranded slot machines with a powerful social hook.

In the same breath that you would espouse integrity and ethical business dealings as being tenets your company hold essential, you promote morally bankrupt developers of the equivalent of digital crack and you personally contribute to harm and issues with addiction for millions of often young or vulnerable users.

It's pretty disgusting that this continues to be a thing. I ask those of you reading this who are actually informed on this problem and know of what I speak, to thumb this up or copy paste it until there's some sort of explanation or Plarium is no longer used as a sponsor. It's something they should be doing an exposé on - not taking cheques from to promote companies that exploit life-destroying addictions.

Some links with info, some directly related and others highlighting some of the issues that are arising with these games and how they operate:

https://youtu.be/xkCSQGsW3n8

https://m.plarium.com/en/arbitration-agreement/

http://www.rovrallovr.net/index.html

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5387773/

https://www.trustpilot.com/review/www.plarium.com

https://www.google.com/amp/s/venturebeat.com/2017/12/04/how-aristocrats-990-million-big-fish-deal-will-shake-up-social-casino-games/amp/

https://moneymag.com.au/aristocrat-gambling-gaming/

https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.citynews1130.com/2016/02/02/dark-side-smartphone-games/amp/

https://interpersonal.stackexchange.com/questions/11853/my-fianc%C3%A9e-is-addicted-to-a-free-to-play-pay-to-win-game

https://www.google.com/amp/s/melmagazine.com/en-us/story/video-games-are-getting-kids-hooked-on-pay-to-win-mechanics/amp
